abstract.p: Robert Fyne letter on Michael Sragow's July 16 article notes Jules Dassin's 1954 film Rififi also spawned Mario Monicelli's Big Deal on Madonna Street (S)

block.p: Certainly Jules Dassin's 1954 ''Rififi'' [''A Noir Classic Makes It Back From the Blacklist'' by Michael Sragow, July 16] inspired such bank and jewelry-heist spinoffs as ''Ocean's Eleven,'' ''Mission: Impossible,'' ''Topkapi'' and, of course, ''The Thomas Crown Affair.'' But it also spawned one of the greatest spoofs of the Italian postwar period, Mario Monicelli's ''Big Deal on Madonna Street'' (1956), a waggish tale in which an inept, happy-go-lucky gang of thieves, bent on robbing a pawn shop by boring a hole through an adjacent building, wind up in the wrong room. Claiming this will be a scientific robbery, these bunglers, featuring Vittorio Gassman, cannot synchronize their watches for this precision break-in because they do not own timepieces. ''Big Deal'' became a worldwide success; in 1983 Louis Malle's remake, ''Crackers,'' put Donald Sutherland in the leading role. Recently, Woody Allen's ''Small Time Crooks'' copycats much of the humor found in Monicelli's satire.
